importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of Truman's presidency marked a major structural overhaul of the White House after years of neglect, including the addition of a bowling alley and the construction of new interior spaces.
The timeframe during which President Harry Truman oversaw the extensive reconstruction of the White House, which included gutting the building and adding a bowling alley and balcony.
The time frame of the Kennedy administration, during which First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy led a major interior restoration and introduced the first televised tour of the White House.
The time frame during which the Resolute Desk was restored, reflecting efforts to preserve historical presidential artifacts and enhance the symbolic value of the White House interior.

keyTakeAways: The White House has undergone numerous renovations throughout U.S. history, reflecting the interests and values of each president and their families.
Presidents have used renovations as a way to leave a personal or symbolic mark on the White House, from FDR’s indoor pool to Truman’s bowling alley and Obama’s basketball court.
Each renovation project has involved significant public funding and has sparked debate over cost, historical preservation, and the role of the White House as a public symbol.
The 1902 renovation under Theodore Roosevelt introduced the West Wing, a key administrative space still in use today.
The 1945–1952 Truman-era renovation gutted much of the building, adding a bowling alley and balcony, and reshaping its interior structure.
First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy led a major restoration in the 1960s, including the restoration of the Resolute Desk and the first televised tour of the White House.
Barack Obama transformed a tennis court into a dual-use basketball and tennis court, reflecting his personal interests and values.
The current trend of renovations under Donald Trump, such as the planned ballroom and goldened Oval Office, continues a long tradition of presidential modernization and personalization.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House has a long history of renovations, with each president leaving a unique mark. From Theodore Roosevelt's 1902 construction of the West Wing and FDR's indoor swimming pool to Truman’s 1945–1952 reconstruction that included a bowling alley, and Jacqueline Kennedy's 1960s restoration featuring the first televised tour and the Resolute Desk, the building has evolved through multiple eras. More recently, President Barack Obama converted a tennis court into a basketball and tennis court, reflecting personal interests. Today, under Donald Trump, new projects like a ballroom and goldened Oval Office continue this tradition of personalization and modernization, showing that the White House remains a dynamic symbol of American political culture and presidential identity.
title: From bowling alley to ballroom - Trump isn't the first to remodel the White House
